sen.j: 一条 富子（いちじょう とみこ、寛保3年2月4日 (旧暦)（1743年2月27日） - 寛政7年11月30日 (旧暦)（1796年1月9日））は、江戸時代中期の皇太后。
sen.e: Tomiko ICHIJO (February 27, 1743-January 9, 1796) was an Empress Dowager during the middle of the Edo period.
Tomiko ICHIJO (February 27, 1743-January 9, 1796) was the Empress Dowager during the middle of the Edo period.

sen.j: 桃園天皇の女御であり、後桃園天皇および伏見宮貞行親王の生母である。
sen.e: She was a Nyogo (a consort) of Emperor Momozono and biological mother of Emperor Gomomozono and Fushimi no Miya Prince Sadamochi.

sen.e: Her junbo (a woman who was given the status equivalent to the emperor's birth mother) was a daughter of Masatoyo ASUKAI, a Gon Dainagon (a provisional major counselor).

sen.j: 一条家の本姓は藤原氏なので藤原富子（ふじわら の とみこ）と記されることもあり。
sen.e: She is sometimes referred to as Tomiko FUJIWARA because the Ichijo family's real family name was Fujiwara.
Her name is sometimes written as FUJIWARA no Tomiko since the Ichijo family's original family name was the Fujiwara clan.

sen.j: 宝暦5年（1755年）10月に従三位に叙され、11月に桃園天皇の後宮に入って女御宣下を受けた。
sen.e: She was conferred Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in November 1755 and received at Emperor Momozono's court as a Nyogo in December.
She was conferred Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in November 1755, and became Nyogo with the imperial proclamation as entering the Emperor Momozono's court in December.
sen.cmt: カンマ、the を補いました。文脈に応じて修正しました。
sen.e: She was conferred Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in November 1755, and became Nyogo with the imperial proclamation as entering the Emperor Momozono's court in December.

sen.j: 宝暦9年（1759年）3月には准三宮の宣下を受ける。
sen.e: She was given the title of Jusangu (honorary rank next to the three Empresses: Great Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empress) in March 1759.
She was given the title of Jusangu (honorary rank next to the three Empresses: Great Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empress) as an imperial proclamation in March 1759.
sen.cmt: as an imperial proclamation を補いました。
sen.e: She was given the title of Jusangu (honorary rank next to the three Empresses: Great Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empress) as an imperial proclamation in March 1759.

sen.j: この年の12月7日に夫の桃園天皇が崩御したが、桃園天皇との間に儲けた第一皇子英仁親王はまだ幼かったので、近臣たちからは即位に早いと止められ、皇位は桃園天皇の姉にあたる後桜町天皇に譲ることとなった。
sen.e: When her husband, Emperor Momozono, passed away on January 24, 1760, Imperial Prince Hidehito, the first Prince whom Emperor Momozono had with her was so young as to be prevented from ascending the throne by trusted vassals, and so the throne was transferred to Emperor Momozono's older sister, who then became Empress Gosakuramachi.

As the Imperial Prince Hidehito, the first prince between her and the Emperor Momozono was too young when the Emperor Momozono passed away on January 24, 1760, his enthronement was halted by trusted vassals due premature age, thus the imperial throne was handed over to his older sister, the Empress Gosakuramachi.
sen.cmt: 文脈に応じて全体を修正しました。
sen.e: As the Imperial Prince Hidehito, the first prince between her and the Emperor Momozono was too young when the Emperor Momozono passed away on January 24, 1760, his enthronement was halted by trusted vassals due premature age, thus the imperial throne was handed over to his older sister, the Empress Gosakuramachi.

sen.j: 明和7年（1770年）に英仁親王が成長すると後桜町天皇から譲位を受けて即位、後桃園天皇となった。
sen.e: In 1770 when Imperial Prince Hidehito grew up enough, he ascended the throne as Emperor Gomomozono, succeeding Empress Gosakuramachi.
In 1770 when the Imperial Prince Hidehito grew up, he ascended the throne as the Emperor Gomomozono, succeeding the Empress Gosakuramachi.

sen.e: In 1770 when the Imperial Prince Hidehito grew up, he ascended the throne as the Emperor Gomomozono, succeeding the Empress Gosakuramachi.

sen.j: 国母となった彼女の地位も大きく上がり、明和8年（1771年）5月9日には皇太后位が授与された。
sen.e: She attained much higher status as an imperial mother and was given the title of Empress Dowager on June 21, 1771.

sen.j: 即日院号授与され、以降は恭礼門院となる。
sen.e: On the same day, she was created a Ingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) and was called Kyoraimonin thereafter.
She was given the Ingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the emperor or a woman of comparable standing) on the same day, and was called Kyoraimonin thereafter.
